key_title: Key to the species of Prunus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Rosaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C.
source.title: Rosaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C. (1996). Rosaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers solitary or in small clusters terminating short lateral shoots; deciduous, leaves thin-textured, usually with some pubescence (sometimes confined to veins on undersurface)
Flowers numerous in axillary racemes; evergreen, leaves thickish, quite glabrous
Mesocarp dry, splitting at maturity; petals pink soon fading to white
Mesocarp fleshy, indehiscent; petals deep pink
Young twigs glabrous, often glossy; fruit with or without a waxy bloom
Young twigs pubescent, dull; fruit usually with a waxy bloom
Drupe more than 30 mm diam.; petals deep pink
Drupe less than 30 mm diam.; petals white or pink
Shoots with terminal buds; pedicle typically much longer than fruit; stone subglobose
Shoots without terminal buds; pedicle shorter than or only slightly longer than fruit; stone flattened, keeled
Divaricately-branched shrubs, spiny at maturity; leaves usually less than 4 cm long; drupe bluish-black, erect, up to 15 mm diam.
Tall shrubs or trees, branches sometimes spiny when young; leaves usually more than 4 cm long; drupe colour variable, pendent, usually more than 20 mm diam.
Racemes shorter to slightly longer than subtending leaves; leaf-margins rather distantly and/or unevenly toothed to entire
Racemes generally c. twice as long as subtending leaves; leaf-margins regularly and closely toothed
